awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Assessing the Commercial Potential of an Advanced Oxide Material for Infrared Detection
awd_abstract_narration:
This I-Corps project will further develop an advanced oxide material for infrared detection. Two technologies dominate the current market for infrared detectors and thermal imagers: semiconductor-based detectors convert incident infrared light into charge carriers, which are then amplified into an electronic signal, while microbolometers directly transform heat into an electronic signal using a heat-sensitive property (usually resistance). In both cases, the read-out circuitry for today's infrared array detectors simply does not scale beyond 1-2 megapixels due to the need for multiple electric leads at each array element. The research team has developed a technology that uses a different approach to infrared detection. Rather than converting infrared photons to carriers, the technology exploits changes in optical properties of an oxide thin film that occur as the material undergoes a thermally-induced phase transition. Conceptually, the technology would enable the replacement of the complicated and expensive read-out circuitry on the back of today's thermal imagers with what is essentially a filter that allows a cheap high-resolution camera to "see" infrared/thermal radiation. The team believes this technology will enable resolutions of over 10 megapixels, more than 10x the state-of-the-art for commercially available uncooled thermal imagers.

The current market for infrared sensors is poised for dramatic growth in areas such as surveillance, transportation, industrial monitoring, energy, and health care. Existing thermal imaging devices are based on unwieldy technologies that have difficulty scaling to resolutions greater than 1-2 megapixels. Thus, advances in imaging processing that have been enabled by high-resolution optical devices cannot be applied to the infrared realm. The technology will address the unmet need of high-resolution thermal imaging by exploiting technological innovations in optical materials to develop a revolutionary product: a high-sensitivity, ultra-high-resolution infrared detector. The team believes the technology could have impact in a wide set of application areas, thus the potential for broad economic and societal impact is high.

por.por_cntn:
This I-Corps project supported a motivated team from the University of Virginia to learn about lean start-up methodology and experience the customer discovery process in order to assess the commercial potential of an advanced oxide material for infrared detection.  The Principal Investigator and collaborators have developed a technology that uses a fundamentally different and innovative approach to infrared detection.  Rather than converting infrared photons to carriers, the technology exploits changes in optical properties of an oxide thin film that occur as the material undergoes a thermally-induced phase transition. The team believed this technology will enable resolutions of over 10 megapixels, more than 10x the state of the art for commercially available uncooled thermal imagers. 

During this I-Corps project we focused on make in-person meetings with the customers and learning their needs.  We have attended several conferences and trade shows.  At the end, we had 110 Customer interviews, 76 out of 110 interviews were conducted in person. During the customer discovery process we talked to companies that regularly partner with start-ups and provide infrared cameras to end-users who require high resolution and high performance. Such companies include defense and security contractors, including Lockheed Martin, Northrop Grumman, and BAE Systems, as well as companies specializing in infrared products, including FLIR, Pelco and Axis.  We talked to end-users of thermal imagers in various application areas, including health care, surveillance, industrial and home monitoring, and transportation.  We also met potential partners, including 4Wave, the company that makes the deposition system used to create the thin films.  We spoke extensively to government agencies and labs who may want to partner in developing out technology, including NASA, defense and intelligence agencies, and National Labs.

At the I-Corps final workshop, we made a “go” decision to continue to pursue commercialization, given the strong product-market fit that we discovered.  Our next step was to build a prototype device so that we could estimate performance metrics for a potential imaging system. 

After the I-Corps workshop, we spoke with a thermal imaging domain expert from the Army Research Lab, who helped us identify a mathematical formula for using the results of a simple measurement to derive several key performance metrics without needing to build a prototype device. To estimate the performance metrics of our thermal imager, we performed the optical measurement to determine the change of optical reflectivity of the oxide thin films as a function of temperature.  The measurement setup is illustrated.  Unfortunately the performance metrics were not competitive with the incumbent technology, and we need to make a pivot on the product/market to pursue other applications of our technology.
